page.title: 17LOCAL HISTORY 1
page.content:
{Towcester}is the{oldest town}in {Northamptonshire}and stands at the junction of the A5{(Watling Street), and the A43 (the Saxon road between Oxford and Northampton). It was called {LACTODORUM}when the Romans fortified it in the 1st Century. It attained importance as a{walled town}defending the Anglo-Saxon kingdom from the Dane law in the 10th Century. It was used by{Prince Rupert}as a Royalist bastion in a predominantly Parliamentarian area during the Civil War. It became a busy{Staging Post}on the route North, when{forty coaches}a day called at Towcester during the 19th Century.
Also, based on pottery, glass and other Roman remains, it is believed that Towcester was for many years an important{administration and tax {collection}centre.
